description: From Ancient Greek ἐργᾰ́της (ergátēs, “labourer, worker”) + English -ive (suffix meaning ‘belong or relating to; of the nature of; serving to; tending to’ forming adjectives).

entries.meaning: (grammar) With the subject of a transitive construction having grammatical cases or thematic relations different from that of an intransitive construction.
examples: The case systems of ergative languages are counter-intuitive to speakers of Indo-European languages.

entries.meaning: Ellipsis of ergative case (“a grammatical case used to indicate the agent of a transitive verb in ergative-absolutive languages”).
An ergative verb or other expression.
